Ada.creator: Jean Ichbiah
Ada.benefits: Strong typing, explicit concurrency, and high reliability.
Ada.description: A statically typed, structured, imperative, and object-oriented high-level language, designed for safety-critical and real-time systems.

Red.creator: Nenad Rakocevic
Red.description: A functional and symbolic language inspired by REBOL.

Assembly.creator: Kathleen Booth
Assembly.benefits: Direct hardware control, maximum performance, zero overhead.
Assembly.description: Low-level symbolic representation of machine code. As close to the metal as you can get.

BASIC.creator: John G. Kemeny, Thomas E. Kurtz
BASIC.benefits: Easy to learn, interactive, historical significance.
BASIC.description: Beginner's All-purpose Symbolic Instruction Code. Designed to emphasize ease of use.
BASIC.history:
BASIC – Concise Summary

Full name: Beginner's All-purpose Symbolic Instruction Code
Created: 1964
Creators: John Kemeny & Thomas Kurtz (Dartmouth College)
Purpose: Make programming easy and accessible for complete beginners and non-science students
Golden era: Mid-1970s to late 1980s (home computer boom)
Most iconic platforms: Commodore 64, Apple II, ZX Spectrum, Atari, TRS-80, early IBM PCs
Key characteristics:
Very simple, English-like commands
Line numbers
Interpreted
Immediate feedback (type & RUN)

Biggest impact: Introduced more people to programming than any other language until Python
Today: Mostly nostalgia/retro + educational value
Still actively used in modern forms (QB64, FreeBASIC, PureBasic, etc.)

In one sentence:
BASIC was the first language designed specifically to let ordinary people start programming easily – and it succeeded spectacularly.

VisualBasic.creator: Microsoft (Alan Cooper)
VisualBasic.benefits: RAD, ease of use, Windows integration, legacy support.
VisualBasic.description: A third-generation event-driven programming language from Microsoft for its Component Object Model (COM) programming model.

Ksh.creator: David Korn
Ksh.description: A Unix shell which was developed by David Korn at Bell Labs in the early 1980s.

Zsh.creator: Paul Falstad
Zsh.description: A Unix shell that can be used as an interactive login shell and as a command interpreter for shell scripting.

Tcl.creator: John Ousterhout
Tcl.description: Tool Command Language. A dynamic programming language.

Awk.creator: Aho, Weinberger, Kernighan
Awk.benefits: Excellent for text processing, one-liners, and data extraction.
Awk.description: A domain-specific language designed for text processing and typically used as a data extraction and reporting tool.

Verilog.creator: Phil Moorby
Verilog.benefits: Hardware modeling, simulation, synthesis, industry standard.
Verilog.description: A hardware description language (HDL) used to model electronic systems.

Smalltalk.creator: Alan Kay, Dan Ingalls, Adele Goldberg
Smalltalk.benefits: Pure OOP, live environment, influence on modern GUIs.
Smalltalk.description: An object-oriented, dynamically typed reflective programming language.
Smalltalk.history:
Smalltalk is a purely object-oriented, dynamically typed, and reflective programming language. Developed in the 1970s at Xerox PARC by a team led by Alan Kay, it was designed to create a "human-computer symbiosis" through an environment that is highly interactive and user-friendly. 
Core Principles and Syntax
Pure Object Orientation: Unlike hybrid languages, everything in Smalltalk is an object, including numbers, classes, and even the execution stack.
Message Passing: Objects communicate exclusively by sending and receiving messages. Smalltalk’s philosophy emphasizes that the "big idea" is the communication between objects rather than the objects themselves.
Minimalist Syntax: The entire language syntax is famously small enough to fit on a postcard, featuring only about six reserved keywords (e.g., nil, true, false, self, super). 
Key Technical Features
Live Coding & Debugging: Developers can modify code while the program is running without needing to restart it. The integrated debugger allows for "rewinding" code execution to fix errors in-place.
Image-Based Development: Instead of traditional files, Smalltalk environments typically use an "image"—a snapshot of the entire system state, including all objects and classes—allowing developers to resume exactly where they left off.
Reflection: Smalltalk programs can inspect and modify their own structure and behavior at runtime, enabling powerful metaprogramming capabilities.
Automatic Memory Management: It was a pioneer in implementing garbage collection, which remains a standard feature in modern versions. 
Historical Impact and Dialects
Smalltalk pioneered many technologies that are now standard in computing, including the Graphical User Interface (GUI), mouse-driven interaction, and the Model-View-Controller (MVC) pattern. It heavily influenced languages such as Java, Python, Ruby, and Objective-C. 
Common Dialects in 2026:
Pharo: A modern, open-source, highly active implementation focused on professional software development.
Squeak: An open-source implementation often used for education and research.
VisualWorks & VAST: Leading commercial versions used for enterprise-grade applications, particularly in the banking and finance sectors.
GNU Smalltalk: A command-line version that follows the ANSI standard closely

C.creator: Dennis Ritchie (Test)
C.benefits: High performance, portability, low-level access, massive legacy.

V.creator: Alexander Medvednikov
V.description: A statically typed, compiled language designed for maintainability and speed.

Objective-C.creator: Brad Cox, Tom Love
Objective-C.benefits: Dynamic runtime, C compatibility, Apple legacy.
Objective-C.description: A general-purpose, object-oriented programming language that adds Smalltalk-style messaging to C.

Zig.creator: Andrew Kelley
Zig.benefits: No hidden control flow, manual memory management, comptime.
Zig.description: A general-purpose programming language and toolchain for maintaining robust, optimal, and reusable software.

Dc.creator: Robert Morris, Lorinda Cherry
Dc.description: A reverse-Polish notation (RPN) calculator that operates on arbitrary-precision integers.

Vala.creator: Jürg Billeter, Rafał Pietrak
Vala.benefits: GObject system, C performance, modern syntax, GNOME dev.
Vala.description: A programming language that aims to bring modern language features to C developers without the overhead of a runtime environment.

XSLT.creator: W3C
XSLT.description: A language for transforming XML documents into other XML documents.

CoffeeScript.creator: Jeremy Ashkenas
CoffeeScript.benefits: Concise syntax, readability, compiles to clean JavaScript.
CoffeeScript.description: A programming language that compiles to JavaScript. It adds syntactic sugar inspired by Ruby, Python and Haskell.

Pascal.creator: Niklaus Wirth
Pascal.description: An imperative and procedural programming language, designed as a small, efficient language intended to encourage good programming practices.

Sed.creator: Lee E. McMahon
Sed.description: A stream editor for filtering and transforming text.

Cobol.creator: CODASYL Committee (Grace Hopper)
Cobol.benefits: Business data processing, stability, massive legacy codebases.
Cobol.description: Common Business-Oriented Language. Designed for business use.

SQLite.creator: D. Richard Hipp
SQLite.description: A C-language library that implements a small, fast, self-contained, high-reliability, full-featured, SQL database engine.

Crystal.creator: Ary Borenszweig
Crystal.benefits: Ruby-like syntax, C-like performance, static typing.
Crystal.description: A general-purpose, object-oriented programming language, designed and implemented by Ary Borenszweig, Juan Wajnerman, Brian Cardiff and more than 300 contributors.

AppleScript.creator: Apple Inc.
AppleScript.description: A scripting language created by Apple Inc. that facilitates automated control over scriptable Mac applications.

Forth.creator: Charles H. Moore
Forth.description: A stack-oriented, concatenative, procedural, and reflective programming language.

Fortran.creator: John Backus
Fortran.description: General-purpose, compiled imperative programming language that is especially suited to numeric computation and scientific computing.

CommonLisp.creator: Committee (Guy L. Steele Jr. et al.)
CommonLisp.benefits: Macros, dynamic typing, interactive development, flexibility.
CommonLisp.description: A dialect of the Lisp programming language, published in ANSI Standard X3.226-1994.

authors.name: Committee (Guy L. Steele Jr. et al.)

Pike.creator: Fredrik Hübinette
Pike.benefits: C-like syntax, dynamic typing, automatic memory management.
Pike.description: A dynamic programming language with a syntax similar to C/C++. Pike features automatic memory management, powerful built-in data types (mappings, multisets, arrays), and excellent support for network protocols. It was originally developed for the Roxen web server.
Pike.history: Pike evolved from LPC (Lars Pensjö C), a language created in 1989 for MUD game development. Fredrik Hübinette developed Pike at Linköping University in Sweden, initially called 'µLPC' before being renamed. The Roxen Internet Software company used Pike extensively for their web server, driving its network programming capabilities. Pike influenced the development of other languages and remains actively maintained.

Fennel.creator: Phil Hagelberg
Fennel.benefits: Lisp syntax, compiles to Lua, zero overhead, embeddable.
Fennel.description: A Lisp dialect that compiles to Lua with zero runtime overhead. Fennel brings powerful macros, pattern matching, and a clean s-expression syntax while leveraging Lua's speed and embeddability. Perfect for game development (LÖVE2D), embedded systems, and anywhere Lua runs.
Fennel.history: Created by Phil Hagelberg (technomancy) in 2016, Fennel was designed to bring the power of Lisp to the Lua ecosystem. Hagelberg, known for creating Leiningen (Clojure's build tool), wanted a Lisp that could run anywhere Lua runs. Fennel gained popularity in the game development community, particularly with LÖVE2D developers. It compiles entirely at build time, producing clean Lua code with no runtime dependencies.

Elixir.creator: José Valim
Elixir.benefits: Concurrency, fault tolerance, functional, Ruby-like syntax.
Elixir.description: A dynamic, functional language designed for building scalable and maintainable applications.

Rexx.creator: Mike Cowlishaw
Rexx.benefits: Scripting, mainframe automation, ease of use.
Rexx.description:
Purpose: Make scripting easy, readable, reliable and powerful – especially for command execution, text processing, macros and automation
Paradigm: Procedural, structured, interpreted (with some compilers available)
Key characteristics:
Extremely readable & English-like syntax
Excellent string manipulation & arbitrary-precision arithmetic
No mandatory variable declaration
Designed to feel "natural" to both beginners and experts

Golden era: 1980s–1990s (especially on IBM mainframes: VM/CMS, TSO, OS/2)
Main platforms today: IBM z/OS, z/VM, IBM i (still built-in), Windows, Linux, macOS via open-source interpreters
Popular implementations (2026):
Regina (classic Rexx)
ooRexx (Object-oriented Rexx) – latest stable ~5.1.0 (2025), beta 5.2.x available
NetRexx (Rexx → Java bytecode)

Current status (January 2026): Niche but very much alive
Strong in mainframe environments
Active open-source community (Rexx Language Association)
37th Rexx Symposium planned for May 2026 in Barcelona
Still used for automation, legacy support, glue scripting


One-sentence verdict:
REXX is the elegant, human-readable "grandfather of modern scripting languages" that remains surprisingly capable and actively maintained — especially on mainframes — more than 45 years after its creation. 🦖
Rexx.history: Restructured Extended Executor. A structured, high-level programming language designed for ease of learning and reading.

Prolog.creator: Alain Colmerauer
Prolog.benefits: Logic programming, AI, pattern matching, declarative.
Prolog.description: A logic programming language associated with artificial intelligence and computational linguistics.

Janet.creator: Calvin Rose
Janet.benefits: Embeddable, small footprint, PEG parsing, functional.
Janet.description: A functional and imperative programming language designed for embedding. The entire language—core library, interpreter, compiler, assembler, and PEG parser—fits in under 1MB. Janet combines Lisp-like syntax with practical features like destructuring, tail-call optimization, and native C interop.
Janet.history: Calvin Rose created Janet in 2017, inspired by Clojure, Lua, and Scheme. Originally named 'dst' (dynamic scripting tool), it was renamed to Janet. The language prioritizes embeddability and small footprint while providing a rich standard library. Janet has found use in game development, scripting, and as an extension language for larger applications.

Wren.creator: Bob Nystrom
Wren.benefits: High performance, small footprint, clean syntax.
Wren.description: A small, fast, class-based concurrent scripting language.

Raku.creator: Larry Wall
Raku.description: A member of the Perl family. Expressive, multi-paradigm, and versatile.Raku is the beautifully expressive, feature-rich evolution of the Perl spirit — a Swiss Army chainsaw reimagined for the 21st century with unmatched parsing power and flexibility, still thriving in a dedicated community in 2026. 🦋
Raku.history:
Creator: Larry Wall + large community effort
Original name: Perl 6 (2000–2019)
Renamed: October 2019 → to reflect it as a distinct sibling language to Perl 5 (not a direct successor)
Purpose: Modern, expressive, highly flexible language that "works the way you think" — fixing Perl's pain points while keeping TIMTOWTDI ("There's More Than One Way To Do It") spirit
Paradigm: Multi-paradigm powerhouse
→ Procedural, Object-Oriented, Functional, Declarative, Metaprogramming + more
Key characteristics:
Gradual / optional typing
Extremely powerful grammars & regexes (best-in-class parsing)
Junctions (any/all logic values)
Lazy evaluation & infinite lists
Unicode everywhere (identifiers, operators)
Invariant sigils, rich sigil system
Hyphenated-names (kebab-case) allowed

Main implementation (2026): Rakudo compiler + MoarVM backend (also JVM & JS backends)
Current status (January 2026):
Stable language level 6.d (Diwali, 2020), with 6.e.PREVIEW features rolling out
Actively developed (~1650 commits in 2025), growing module ecosystem (508 updates in 2025), passionate niche community, monthly Rakudo releases
Adoption: Niche / enthusiastic — strong in text processing, DSLs, scripting, parsing; under-the-radar but loved by its users

Fish.creator: Axel Liljencrantz
Fish.description: A smart and user-friendly command line shell for macOS, Linux, and the rest of the family.

PostScript.creator: John Warnock, Charles Geschke
PostScript.benefits: Printing, vector graphics, stack-based, device independence.
PostScript.description: A page description language in the electronic publishing and desktop publishing business.

Gnuplot.creator: Thomas Williams, Colin Kelley
Gnuplot.description: A command-line program that can generate two- and three-dimensional plots of functions, data, and data fits.

Jq.creator: Stephen Dolan
Jq.description: A lightweight and flexible command-line JSON processor.

OCaml.creator: Xavier Leroy et al.
OCaml.benefits: Functional, type safety, performance, industrial strength.
OCaml.description: A general-purpose, multi-paradigm programming language which extends the Caml dialect of ML with object-oriented features.

Haxe.creator: Nicolas Cannasse
Haxe.description: A high-level cross-platform language that compiles to many other languages.
Haxe.history:
Purpose: True write once, compile anywhere – single codebase targeting many platforms natively
Paradigm: Multi-paradigm (strongly object-oriented + functional + generic)
Typing: Strictly & statically typed (with excellent type inference + optional dynamic)
Syntax style: Modern, ECMAScript / ActionScript / Java-like, very familiar to JS / TS / Java / C# devs
Key strength: Extremely powerful cross-compiler → produces source code or bytecode for many targets
Main targets (2026): JavaScript, C++, C#, Java/JVM, Python, PHP, Lua, HashLink (own fast VM), NekoVM + interpreted mode
Used for: Games (Dead Cells, Papers, Please), web, mobile, desktop, backend, tools
Popular frameworks: OpenFL, Heaps.io, Kha, HaxeFlixel, Armory3D
Current status (Jan 2026): Very active – latest stable: 4.3.7 (May 2025), Haxe 5.0 preview already out

One-sentence verdict:
Haxe is the most mature and performant "compile-to-many-languages" language that lets you write modern, type-safe code once and target almost every major platform natively — still somewhat under the radar but loved by its users. 🚀

F_Sharp.creator: Don Syme
F_Sharp.description: A functional-first programming language that encompasses functional, imperative, and object-oriented programming methods. F# brings functional-first programming to .NET with strong typing, succinct syntax and excellent interop.

Clojure.creator: Rich Hickey
Clojure.benefits: Immutability, functional programming, JVM interoperability, simplicity.
Clojure.description: A dynamic, general-purpose programming language, combining the approachability and interactive development of a scripting language with an efficient and robust infrastructure for multithreaded programming. It brings Lisp's code-as-data and immutable data structures to the JVM.

Bash.creator: Brian Fox
Bash.benefits: Ubiquitous, powerful scripting, direct system interaction.
Bash.related: Bourne Shell, C Shell, KornShell, Zsh
Bash.description: The Bourne Again SHell. The default shell for most Linux distributions and macOS. It unified scripting and interactive use on Unix-like systems. Beyond interactive shells, Bash scripts glue together tools, automate builds and manage system tasks.

C_Sharp.creator: Anders Hejlsberg
C_Sharp.benefits: Strong typing, rich .NET ecosystem, modern features, tooling.
C_Sharp.related: C++, Java, Delphi, Modula-3, F#, Visual Basic .NET
C_Sharp.description: A modern, object-oriented, and type-safe programming language derived from C and C++. Designed to support enterprise, desktop and web applications on the .NET platform. It emphasizes tooling, libraries and developer productivity.

C++.creator: Bjarne Stroustrup
C++.benefits: Performance, object-oriented, rich ecosystem, hardware control.
C++.related: C, Simula, Ada, Rust, D, Java, C#
C++.description: Multi-paradigm language combining procedural and object-oriented programming. It extended C with abstractions like classes and templates to enable both low-level control and high-level design. C++ powers performance-critical applications, from game engines to embedded systems.

Scheme.creator: Guy L. Steele, Gerald Jay Sussman
Scheme.benefits: Minimalist, clean semantics, first-class procedures, educational.
Scheme.description: A minimalist Lisp dialect focusing on clean semantics and first-class procedures; Scheme is central in programming language education.

Dart.creator: Lars Bak, Kasper Lund
Dart.description: Created for structured client-side development, Dart powers Flutter for cross-platform UIs and compiles to efficient native or JS code.

Erlang.creator: Joe Armstrong, Robert Virding, Mike Williams
Erlang.description: Designed for telecoms, Erlang emphasizes lightweight processes, message-passing concurrency and robust fault-recovery.

Vimscript.creator: Bram Moolenaar
Vimscript.description: The scripting language built into Vim for customizing and extending the editor. Vimscript supports variables, functions, lists, dictionaries, and autocommands. It powers Vim's plugin ecosystem, enabling everything from syntax highlighting to complex IDE-like features.
Vimscript.history: Bram Moolenaar created Vimscript alongside Vim in 1991 as an evolution of vi's ex commands. Over decades, it evolved from simple mappings to a full scripting language. Vim 7 (2006) added lists, dictionaries, and other modern features. While Neovim has adopted Lua as an alternative, Vimscript remains the primary language for Vim configuration and many plugins. Vim 9 introduced Vim9 script with improved performance.

Octave.creator: John W. Eaton
Octave.description: A high-level language for numerical computations, providing a command-line interface for solving linear and nonlinear problems, and for performing other numerical experiments. Octave is largely compatible with MATLAB, making it a popular free alternative for scientific computing and engineering.
Octave.history: John W. Eaton began developing GNU Octave in 1988 as a companion to a chemical reactor design textbook. The first alpha release came in 1993, with version 1.0 in 1994. Named after Octave Levenspiel, a chemical engineering professor, Octave grew into a full numerical computing environment. It became part of the GNU Project and is widely used in academia and industry as a free MATLAB alternative.

Dash.creator: Herbert Xu
Dash.description: The Debian Almquist Shell—a POSIX-compliant shell that is significantly smaller and faster than bash. Dash is optimized for executing shell scripts quickly and is the default /bin/sh on Debian and Ubuntu systems, where it handles system scripts during boot.
Dash.history: Herbert Xu ported the NetBSD Almquist shell (ash) to Linux in 1997, creating Dash. The Almquist shell itself was created by Kenneth Almquist as a lightweight Bourne shell replacement. Debian adopted Dash as /bin/sh in 2006 to speed up boot times and script execution. Ubuntu followed in 2006. Dash focuses purely on POSIX compliance and speed, deliberately omitting bash-isms to encourage portable scripts.

Make.creator: Stuart Feldman
Make.description: A build automation tool that automatically builds executable programs and libraries from source code by reading files called Makefiles. Make uses dependency graphs to determine which parts of a program need to be recompiled, dramatically reducing build times for large projects.
Make.history: Stuart Feldman created Make at Bell Labs in 1976, winning the ACM Software System Award for it in 2003. The original Make was part of Unix Version 7. GNU Make, written by Richard Stallman and Roland McGrath, added powerful extensions. Make's declarative approach to build dependencies influenced countless build systems. Despite modern alternatives like CMake, Ninja, and language-specific tools, Make remains ubiquitous in Unix development.

Bc.creator: Robert Morris, Lorinda Cherry
Bc.description: An arbitrary-precision calculator language with syntax similar to C. Bc (basic calculator) supports variables, functions, and control flow, making it useful for both interactive calculations and scripting. It's a standard Unix utility found on virtually all Unix-like systems.
Bc.history: Robert Morris and Lorinda Cherry created bc at Bell Labs in 1975 as a front-end to dc (desk calculator). While dc uses reverse Polish notation, bc provides a more familiar infix syntax. Bc was included in Version 6 Unix. POSIX standardized bc, and GNU bc added extensions like the 'read' function. Bc remains the go-to tool for shell scripts needing floating-point or arbitrary-precision math, as most shells only support integer arithmetic.

Jupyter.creator: Fernando Pérez, Brian Granger
Jupyter.benefits: Interactive computing, notebooks, data science, visualization.
Jupyter.description: An open-source web application for creating and sharing documents with live code, equations, and visualizations.

Perl.creator: Larry Wall
Perl.benefits: Text processing, regex, CPAN ecosystem, system administration.
Perl.description: A highly capable, feature-rich programming language with powerful text processing capabilities.

Tcsh.creator: Ken Greer
Tcsh.benefits: C-shell compatible, command-line editing, job control.
Tcsh.description: An enhanced version of the Berkeley C shell (csh) featuring programmable command-line completion, command-line editing, history mechanism, and a more user-friendly interactive experience. Tcsh was the default shell on FreeBSD and early macOS versions.
Tcsh.history: Ken Greer developed tcsh at Carnegie Mellon University in 1981, adding command completion to Bill Joy's original C shell. The name comes from the 'T' in TENEX, an operating system known for its command completion. Paul Placeway later added command-line editing. Tcsh became popular on BSD systems and was the default shell on Mac OS X until Panther (10.3). While largely superseded by bash and zsh for interactive use, tcsh remains available on most Unix systems.

Icon.creator: Ralph Griswold
Icon.description: A very high-level programming language based on goal-directed execution and string scanning. It makes extensive use of generators and backtracking.

Brainfuck.creator: Urban Müller
Brainfuck.description: An esoteric programming language consisting of only eight single-character commands: > < + - . , [ ]. Despite this extreme minimalism, Brainfuck is Turing complete. It operates on a tape of memory cells, with a pointer that can move left or right, increment or decrement cells, and loop based on cell values.
Brainfuck.history: Urban Müller created Brainfuck in 1993 with the goal of designing a language with the smallest possible compiler. The original compiler was only 296 bytes. The language was inspired by FALSE, another minimalist language. Brainfuck sparked interest in esoteric programming languages and inspired numerous derivatives like Ook!, Whitespace, and Malbolge. It's often used to teach concepts of Turing machines and low-level computation.

Scala.creator: Martin Odersky
Scala.benefits: Functional + OOP, JVM, type safety, concurrency (Akka).
Scala.related: Java, ML, Haskell, Smalltalk, Erlang, Kotlin
Scala.description: A strong statically typed general-purpose programming language which supports both object-oriented programming and functional programming. Scala fuses object-oriented and functional programming on the JVM.
Scala.history: 2004. Scala fuses object-oriented and functional programming on the JVM, enabling concise, type-safe code for large systems and data pipelines.

Rust.creator: Graydon Hoare
Rust.benefits: Memory safety, concurrency, performance, no GC.
Rust.related: C++, ML, Haskell, Erlang, Swift, C
Rust.description: A multi-paradigm, general-purpose programming language designed for safety and performance. It targets safe, concurrent systems programming with compile-time guarantees that prevent many classes of runtime errors.
Rust.history: 2010. Rust targets safe, concurrent systems programming with compile-time guarantees that prevent many classes of runtime errors while delivering native performance.

Groovy.creator: James Strachan
Groovy.benefits: Java compatibility, scripting, dynamic features, DSLs.
Groovy.description: A Java-syntax-compatible object-oriented programming language for the Java platform. It is a dynamic language with features similar to Python, Ruby, and Smalltalk, used for build scripts, DSLs and rapid prototyping.
Groovy.history: 2003. A dynamic JVM language that blends scripting ergonomics with Java interoperability; Groovy is used for build scripts, DSLs and rapid prototyping.

Julia.creator: Jeff Bezanson, Stefan Karpinski, Viral B. Shah, Alan Edelman
Julia.benefits: Speed of C, ease of Python, great for scientific computing.
Julia.description: A high-level, high-performance dynamic programming language for technical computing. It combines easy syntax with high-performance JIT-compiled code, reducing the need for separate prototyping and production languages.
Julia.history: 2012. Built for numerical and scientific computing, Julia combines easy syntax with high-performance JIT-compiled code, reducing the need for separate prototyping and production languages.

Swift.creator: Chris Lattner et al.
Swift.benefits: Safety, performance, modern syntax, Apple ecosystem.
Swift.description: A general-purpose, multi-paradigm, compiled programming language developed by Apple. Swift has largely superseded Objective-C for Apple platform development, focusing on safety, performance and developer ergonomics.
Swift.history: 2014. Apple's modern language focusing on safety, performance and developer ergonomics; Swift has largely superseded Objective-C for Apple platform development.
